article.title: Erd%C5%91s_number
article.paragraph: TheErds number(IPA-huˈɛrdøːʃ) describes the "collaborative distance" between mathematiciannobr[[Paul Erdős]]and another person, as measured by authorship ofList of important publications in mathematicsmathematical papers.

The same principle has been applied in other fields where a particular individual has collaborated with a large and broad number of peers. TheAmerican Mathematical Societyprovides a free online tool to determine the Erds number of every mathematical author listed in theMathematical Reviewscatalogue.cite webhttp://www.ams.org/mathscinet/collaborationDistance.html Collaboration Distance[[MathSciNet]]American Mathematical Society
article.heading: Overview
article.paragraph: Paul Erds (19131996) was an influential mathematician who spent a large portion of his later life writing papers with a large number of colleagues, working on solutions to outstanding mathematical problems.cite journalNewmanM. E. J.Mark NewmanThe structure of scientific collaboration networksProc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA200110.1073/pnas.021544898982404–4091114995214598He published more papers during his lifetime (at least 1,525cite webhttp://www.oakland.edu/enp/pubinfo/Publications of Paul ErdősJerryGrossman1 Feb 2011) than any other mathematician in history.(Leonhard Eulerpublished more total pages of mathematics but fewer separate papers: about 800.)cite webhttps://www.math.dartmouth.edu/~euler/FAQ.htmlThe Euler ArchiveFrequently Asked QuestionsDartmouth UniversityErds spent a large portion of his later life living out of a suitcase, visiting his over 500 collaborators around the world.

The idea of the Erds number was originally created by the mathematician's friends as a tribute to his enormous output. However, in later years it gained prominence as a tool to study how mathematicians cooperate to find answers to unsolved problems. Several projects are devoted to studying connectivity among researchers, using the Erds number as a proxy.cite webhttp://www.oakland.edu/enpErdös Number ProjectOakland UniversityFor example, Erdscollaboration graphscan tell us how authors cluster, how the number of co-authors per paper evolves over time, or how new theories propagate.cite webhttp://www.oakland.edu/enp/trivia/Facts about Erdös Numbers and the Collaboration GraphErdös Number ProjectOakland University

Several studies have shown that leading mathematicians tend to have particularly low Erds numbers.cite journalDe CastroRodrigo GrossmanJerrold W. 10.1007/BF03025416 3 [[The Mathematical Intelligencer]] 1709679 51–63 Famous trails to Paul Erdős http://www.oakland.edu/upload/docs/Erdos%20Number%20Project/trails.pdf 21 1999Original Spanish version inRev. Acad. Colombiana Cienc. Exact. Fs. Natur.23(89) 563582, 1999,MR1744115.For example, only 134,007 mathematicians have an Erds number, with a median value of 5.whenMay 2015In contrast, the median Erds number ofFields Medalistsis 3.cnMay 2015Only 7,097 (about 5%) of mathematicians with a collaboration path have an Erds number of 2 or lower.whenMay 2015As time goes on, the smallest Erds number that can still be achieved will necessarily increase, as mathematicians with low Erds numbers die and become unavailable for collaboration.
article.heading: Definition and application in mathematics
article.paragraph: File:Erdosnumber.pngthumbIfAlice and BobAlicecollaborates with Paul Erds on one paper, and with Bob on another, but Bob never collaborates with Erds himself, then Alice is given an Erds number of 1 and Bob is given an Erds number of 2, as he is two steps from Erds.To be assigned an Erds number, someone must be a coauthor of a research paper with another person who has a finite Erds number. Paul Erds has an Erds number of zero. Anybody else's Erds number ismath''k'' + 1wheremath''k''is the lowest Erds number of any coauthor.

Erds wrote around 1,500 mathematical articles in his lifetime, mostly co-written. He had 511 direct collaborators;these are the people with Erds number 1. The people who have collaborated with them (but not with Erds himself) have an Erds number of 2 (9267 people as of 2010Erdos2, Version 2010, October 20, 2010.), those who have collaborated with people who have an Erds number of 2 (but not with Erds or anyone with an Erds number of 1) have an Erds number of 3, and so forth. A person with no such coauthorship chain connecting to Erds has an Erds number ofinfinity(or andefined and undefinedundefinedone). Since the death of Paul Erds, the lowest Erds number that a new researcher can obtain is 2.

There is room for ambiguity over what constitutes a link between two authors. TheAmerican Mathematical Societycollaboration distance calculator uses data fromMathematical Reviews, which includes most mathematics journals but covers other subjects only in a limited way, and which also includes some non-research publicationsfactAugust 2015. The Erds Number Project web site says:quote... Our criterion for inclusion of an edge between vertices u and v is some research collaboration between them resulting in a published work. Any number of additional co-authors is permitted,...but they do not include non-research publications such as elementary textbooks, joint editorships, obituaries, and the like. The Erds number of the second kind restricts assignment of Erds numbers to papers with only two collaborators.Grossmanet al."Erds numbers of the second kind," inFacts about Erds Numbers and the Collaboration Graph.The Erds Number Project,Oakland University, USA. Retrieved July 25, 2009.

The Erds number was most likely first defined in print by Casper Goffman, anMathematical analysisanalystwhose own Erds number is 2.Goffman published his observations about Erds' prolific collaboration in a 1969 article entitled "And what is your Erds number?"cite journalGoffmanCasperAnd what is your Erdős number?[[American Mathematical Monthly]]76196910.2307/231786879123178687See also some comments in an obituary by Michael Golomb.Erds' obituary by Michael Golomb

The median Erds number amongFields medalistsis as low as 3.Fields medalists with Erds number 2 includeAtle Selberg,Kunihiko Kodaira,Klaus Roth,Alan Baker (mathematician)Alan Baker,Enrico Bombieri,David Mumford,Charles Fefferman,William Thurston,Shing-Tung Yau,Jean Bourgain,Richard Borcherds,Manjul Bhargava,Jean-Pierre SerreandTerence Tao. There are no Fields medalists with Erds number 1,cite webhttp://www.oakland.edu/enp/erdpaths/Paths to ErdösThe Erdös Number ProjectOakland UniversityhoweverEndre Szemerdiis anAbel PrizeLaureate with Erds number 1.
article.heading: Most frequent Erds collaborators
article.paragraph: While Erds collaborated with hundreds of co-authors, there were some individuals with whom he co-authored dozens of papers. This is a list of the ten persons who most frequently co-authored with Erds and their number of papers co-authored with Erds (i.e. their number of collaborations).Grossman, Jerry,Erdos0p, Version 2010,The Erds Number Project,Oakland University, USA, October 20, 2010.

article.heading: Impact
article.paragraph: File:Paul Erdos with Terence Tao.jpgthumbPaul Erds teachingTerence Taoin 1985 at the University of Adelaide. Tao, who was 10 years old at the time, became a professional mathematician. He received the Fields Medal in 2006 and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2007. Tao has an Erds number of 2Erds numbers have been a part of thefolkloreof mathematicians throughout the world for many years. Among all working mathematicians at the turn of the millennium who have a finite Erds number, the numbers range up to 15, the median is 5, and the mean is 4.65;almost everyone with a finite Erds number has a number less than 8. Due to the very high frequency of interdisciplinary collaboration in science today, very large numbers of non-mathematicians in many other fields of science also have finite Erds numbers.cite webhttp://www.oakland.edu/enp/erdpaths/Some Famous People with Finite Erdős NumbersJerryGrossman1 February 2011For example, political scientistSteven Bramshas an Erds number of 2. In biomedical research, it is common for statisticians to be among the authors of publications, and many statisticians can be linked to Erds viaJohn Tukey, who has an Erds number of 2. Similarly, the prominent geneticistEric Landerand the mathematicianDaniel Kleitmanhave collaborated on papers,A dictionary-based approach for gene annotation. [J Comput Biol. 1999 Fall-Winter] - PubMed ResultPMID10582576cite webhttp://www-math.mit.edu/~djk/list.htmlPublications Since 1980 more or lessDanielKleitmanDaniel Kleitman[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]and since Kleitman has an Erds number of 1,cite journalErdősPaulPaul ErdősDaniel KleitmanKleitmanDanielOn Collections of Subsets Containing No 4-Member Boolean Algebra[[Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society]]28187–90April 197110.2307/20377622037762a large fraction of the genetics and genomics community can be linked via Lander and his numerous collaborators. Similarly, collaboration withGustavus Simmonsopened the door forList of people by Erds numberErds numberswithin thecryptographicresearch community, and manylinguisticslinguistshave finite Erds numbers, many due to chains of collaboration with such notable scholars asNoam Chomsky(Erds number 4),cite webvon FintelKaiMy Erdös Number is 8http://semantics-online.org/2004/01/my-erds-number-is-8Semantics, Inc.2004https://web.archive.org/web/20060823085712/http://semantics-online.org/2004/01/my-erds-number-is-823 August 2006William Labov(3),cite webhttp://www.ling.upenn.edu/~dinkin/Aaron Dinkin has a web site?Ling.upenn.edu2010-08-29Mark Liberman(3),cite webhttp://www.ling.upenn.edu/~myl/Mark Liberman's Home PageLing.upenn.edu2010-08-29Geoffrey Pullum(3),cite webhttp://www.stanford.edu/~cgpotts/miscellany.htmlChristopher Potts: MiscellanyStanford.edu2010-08-29orIvan Sag(4).cite webhttp://lingo.stanford.edu/sag/erdos.htmlBob's Erdős NumberLingo.stanford.edu2010-08-29There are also connections withartsfields.cite conferenceBowenJonathan P.Jonathan BowenWilsonRobin J.Robin Wilson (mathematician)StuartDunnJonathan P.BowenKiaNgVisualising Virtual Communities: From Erdős to the Artshttp://ewic.bcs.org/content/ConWebDoc/46141EVA London 2012: Electronic Visualisation and the Arts[[British Computer Society]]Electronic Workshops in Computing238–24410–12 July 2012
According to Alex Lopez-Ortiz, all theFields MedalFieldsandNevanlinna PrizeNevanlinna prizewinners during the three cycles in 1986 to 1994 have Erds numbers of at most 9.

Earlier mathematicians published fewer papers than modern ones, and more rarely published jointly written papers. The earliest person known to have a finite Erds number is eitherRichard Dedekind(born 1831, Erds number 7) orFerdinand Georg Frobenius(born 1849, Erds number 3), depending on the standard of publication eligibility.cite webhttp://www.oakland.edu/?idPaths to Erdös - The Erdös Number Project- Oakland Universityoakland.eduIt seems that older historic figures such asLeonhard Euler(born 1707) do not (yet) have finite Erds numbers.

Tompacite journalTompaMartinFigures of meritACM SIGACT News20162–71198910.1145/65780.65782cite journalTompaMartinFigures of merit: the sequelACM SIGACT News21478–81199010.1145/101371.101376proposed adirected graphversion of the Erds number problem, by orienting edges of the collaboration graph from the alphabetically earlier author to the alphabetically later author and defining themonotone Erds numberof an author to be the length of alongest pathfrom Erds to the author in this directed graph. He finds a path of this type of length 12.

Also,Michael Barr (mathematician)Michael Barrsuggests "rational Erds numbers", generalizing the idea that a person who has written p joint papers with Erds should be assigned Erds number 1/p. From the collaboration multigraph of the second kind (although he also has a way to deal with the case of the first kind)with one edge between two mathematicians foreachjoint paper they have producedform an electrical network with a one-ohm resistor on each edge. The total resistance between two nodes tells how "close" these two nodes are.

It has been argued that "for an individual researcher, a measure such as Erds number captures the structural properties of [the] network whereas theh-index''h''-indexcaptures the citation impact of the publications," and that "One can be easily convinced that ranking in coauthorship networks should take into account both measures to generate a realistic and acceptable ranking."Kashyap Dixit, S Kameshwaran, Sameep Mehta, Vinayaka Pandit, N Viswanadham,Towards simultaneously exploiting structure and outcomes in interaction networks for node ranking, IBM Research Report R109002, February 2009; also appeared asCite journal10.1145/1871437.1871470KameshwaranS.PanditV.MehtaS.ViswanadhamN.DixitK.Outcome aware ranking in interaction networks229-2382010978-1-4503-0099-5Proceedings of the 19th ACM international conference on Information and knowledge management (CIKM '10)

article.heading: Variations
article.paragraph: A number of variations on the concept have been proposed to apply to other fields.

The best known isBacon number(as in the gameSix Degrees of Kevin Bacon), connecting actors that appeared in a film together to the actorKevin Bacon.Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon#HistoryIt was created in 1994, 25 years after Goffman's article on the Erds number.

A small number of people are connected to both Erds and Bacon and thus have anErdsBacon number, which combines the two numbers by taking their sum. One example is the actress-mathematicianDanica McKellar, best known for playing Winnie Cooper on the TV series,The Wonder Years. Her Erds number is 4McKellar's co-author L. Chayes published a paper with E.H. Lieb, who in turn co-authored a paper with D.J. Kleitman, a co-author of Paul Erds.and her Bacon number is 2.Danica McKellar was in "The Year That Trembled" (2002) with James Kisicki , who was in "Telling Lies in America" (1997) with Kevin Bacon.The lowest knownErdsBacon number is 3 forDaniel Kleitman, a mathematics professor at MIT his Erds number is 1 and his Bacon number is 2.Daniel J. Kleitman,"My Career in the Movies,",Notices of the American Mathematical Society,45, 502 (April 1998)

Further generalization is possible. For example, ErdsBaconSabbath numbers include the bandBlack Sabbathin the measure.cite webhttp://erdosbaconsabbath.com/EBS Projecterdosbaconsabbath.comThe lowest known ErdsBaconSabbath number is 8, a value shared by physicistStephen Hawking,The EBS project - Stephen HawkingneuroscientistDaniel Levitincite webhttp://erdosbaconsabbath.com/daniel-levitin/EBS Projecterdosbaconsabbath.comand inventorRay Kurzweil,cite webhttp://erdosbaconsabbath.com/ray-kurzweil/EBS Projecterdosbaconsabbath.comall of whom have an Erds number of 4, a Bacon number of 2, and a Sabbath number of 2.
